review_title: Employee salaries "if you want more money, work more overtime"
pros: At the end of the quarter, Honeywell usually supplies food for their employees as an incentive for them to work on weekends.
cons: My average yearly raise was less than 50 cents. Employees aren't awarded for their dedication. Every year, there is a "employee review" where your supervisor rates your work, productivity, and so forth. I was there for 4 years and each year I had a new supervisor. Many people didnt agree with their reviews and refused to sign them. These reviews determine your raise. The raises weren't enough to compensate for inflation. Honeywell has the mentality of "if you want more money, work more overtime" and that's not okay. If they gave proper raises, you wouldn't have to work those extra hours.

review_title: Great company to build a career
job_title: Sr Offering Management Specialist in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
I've been in Honeywell for almost 5 years now and in the time I've been here I've been given several opportunities to grow in my career. Support from the leadership teams I've been part of has been exceptional. Also, there's not only vertical movements within the org. but also lateral moves, making it really accessible to explore different areas of the business. 

Another thing I really like about Honeywell is the commitment to ethics and compliance as well as the entire structure they have to ensure this happens without having a single point reviewing that compliance is met. Instead there's a matrix of people and employees are empowered to be part of this matrix. Being a company with values really creates a very healthy work environment.
cons: Honeywell could provide some additional benefits and/or events for it's employees.

pros: Average benefits; every year the benefits are less and less and now they are really not comparable to peer companies. There is truly so much work to do that it is certainly possible to find something to your liking. Being such a big company, it is easier for some folks to pass through many years without really having to carry too much weight.
cons: Benefits are really lagging. Upper management is always super upbeat because things are so backwards that nobody can manage with transparency; it is a constant spin of reality vs what the company wants you to believe. There is so much work and not enough people to do it that they are constantly are looking for ways to shame you into putting "extra professional" time. And constantly coming up with made up terms to explain the total mismanagement at the technical level; latest one "under absorption" to let you know management overcommitted to too much work without enough workforce, so they expect everyone to work more hours to show higher "efficiency" but people can only keep up with 60+ hr weeks for so long, so people leave or stop working the "extra professional" time, the company will not hire more people, so the end result is that people are "under absorbed", or in other words not working enough to meet all the work that is out there. The work-life balance truly is atrocious in the last 5years or so (expectation is to be available 24/7).

pros:
Global work assignments 
Diverse business lines
cons:
Honeywell thinks its 2020 Amazon but operates like 1985 GE.
Powerpoint is still utilized DAILY as the preferred communications choice.
The "flexible" WFH policy isn't flexible at all-Management does keep track of in-office attendance on a daily basis.
Your in-office days are spent on video team meetings.
Do not fall for the "Unlimited" PTO policy-be prepared to have meetings, receive phone calls, and "everything is an emergency" atmosphere. Work/life balance is almost non-existent.

pros: Very good salary. Very good to get a beginner grasp on legal career/environment (how to draft agreement, how to execute them, why and what they are, legal authorities).
cons: Very sad and ugly office location far away from the center. Outdated and dirty desks, monitors, chairs. NOT friendly and LOUD environment. ZERO support on the process. Noone outside you will know the process and you will work with people that DOES NOT know the process and what you are doing and why. Total chaos. Very strict policy based on approvals and approvals for everything including many mandatory trainings. VERY poor and almost nont exhistent work from home policy. HIGH turnover. Very stressfull and high pressure job. Agreements and agreements over and over no stop. ZERO respect on professional boundaries. Hysterical reaction for every single agreement. Not cooperative environment. NO team work.

review_title: Great opportunity for growth but lacking the tools needed for success

The lack of training produced over the last few years has been a joke which is not the best to see when you are responsible for thousands of lives on the aircraft that your unit may be on.

review_title: Honeywell: we demand you relo and we will charge you back if you leave
pros: Free snacks, new campus in Charlotte, free parking, global projects
cons:
Do not relocate until you are 100% sure you're gonna a) like it and b) they're not planning to RIF your job 

While I learned a bunch, there was too many toxic leaders and I left after about a year and a half. The relo period bwas 2 years. Stupid me. 

I had positive reviews on my annual feedback session and even got my full bonus and a raise.

Guess what...they wanted full freight on my relo. 

Full. Freaking. Freight 

This amounted to almost $90,000. 

Yes you read that right.

Me: But I worked for a year and a half and did really well. Would you consider a making it 50%

HR: F U Pay me

Me: But this will cripple me. Other companies are a bit more lenient on their relo policies after time served.

HR: F U Pay me

Me: I can't do this without it impacting my livelihood and I may have to default on other financial obligations. Aren't you concerned about how this may affect your reputation?

HR: F U PAY ME..or we go to collections

It will absolutely happen to you. Buyer beware

review_title: Mixed Bag — Better than Most Big Companies
pros:
I’ve had a better support system than my previous jobs. My immediate team / function wasn’t the nicest, but made good connections across the country / world due to the regular work with international sites. It didn’t take long to start building a network, remotely and in person, that helped provide support, advice, and helped steer my career. I really love getting to work with and meet so many people from across the world, best experience I’ve had with international work at all. 

I’ve had some drama with coworkers and a mediocre manager, but less than I’m used too. There are a few cliques, but surprisingly few given the companies size. Allied Signal was not highly regarded, and those from Allied tend to be…gruff…at best. However, Garrett and the original Honeywell tend to brighten up the workplace.

If nothing else, Honeywell is huge, and offers a lot of possibilities and helps you along to them. Excited to move to a new role in a new function that’ll support teams worldwide, a dream come true.
cons:
Company wise, the work from home policy; it’s draconian at best. Many originally expected to be forced to go back full time in 2022, but enough employee surveys demanding WFH stay forced corporate to keep a flex schedule of three days in the office and two days at home. Nonetheless, it came, and still continues to come with a strong discouragement of work from home in general. I had to go back to work on a flex schedule on July 2021 while every other tech and aerospace company wasn’t even fathoming in office work. Fortunately, the flex schedule is here to stay, but the company’s resistance is a definite draw back. It’s primarily the CEO fighting it, seems he’s losing though, so the company is quietly starting to remove or silence opposition to WFH. 

Honeywell Aero is particularly disorganized to the point that it affects day to day work. The company historically has cut key functions that now underperform due to low staffing and other functions are expected to pick up the slack, just cause. Have to work with a number of people who lack the knowledge and understanding of our own internal systems and data while demanding an explanation for changes their function controls  — not realizing their function even does do the activity they’re questioning. 

The company is WAY too management heavy. I’m no stranger to elaborate corporate hierarchies, but Honeywell seemed to take overhead to the max. The company joke is that “at Honeywell, you’ll have two VPs, four directors, five managers,  and all their support staff on a status call given by one individual contributor who actually works a revenue generating product”. This company doesn’t seem to think that it’s questionable that 3 levels of a organization are on every call together — if the VP is in every call, why is there two directors and four managers on the same calls? You can see it costs the company a lot to have all this management by how quickly they remove perks like free coffee, the cafeteria, etc. to save a quick buck.

review_title: Honeywell could be a great place to work... but it just isn't.
pros: Financially Honeywell is a stable company that aims to take care of its shareholders. The people are great.
cons:
The company is in constant endless churn. I have had 3 different bosses in the last 2 years. Mid level management spends more time bringing new senior leadership teams up to speed than time spent focusing on customer needs. The inner workings of the company from its ERP systems to its Sourcing and HR policies are so complicated and riddled with red tape it is nearly impossible to carry out the company charter to impose any real, novel new ideas and solutions for its customers.
As a result, the company has a big employee retention problem. And its no wonder. In addition to points above, the company pays industry average salaries and wages. When being promoted, the worker will have to aggressively negotiate merit increases, otherwise HR will be happy to award you a pat on the back a consider you lucky with a 1-1.5%% increase in salary to award you for taking on more responsibilities. Which in many cases dis enchants employees and causes the employee to take a new job elsewhere. There are 0 thing this company does to retain talent. No retention bonuses, vesting stock or stock options, or pensions. Honeywell has an industry average contribution to your 401K. There is a no vacation policy. This is sold to the employee as "you can take as much time off as you want- as long as your boss approves it". This leaves senior long term employees who've spent a career earning more vacation time every year with basically the same amount of vacation time as the new hire right out of college. And don't expect HR to be on your side. Your HR rep has no power to advocate on your behalf when it comes to title, merit increases, bonuses or benefits.

pros: The people that I work with are friendly and eager to help. Manager is friendly, helpful, has open door communication. I don't feel like I'm being micro-managed and team around you really empowers you to be a leader with your project and areas you can influence. Competitive salary. Flexible work schedule. Transparent internal job postings. Work culture and I&D efforts.
cons: I have some concerns for how future layoffs may be handled since I get the feeling they recently had a massive layoff that cut too deep. This has led to loss of experience, lack of documentation, and a poor transition of people. Training and onboarding could be improved.

review_title: Typical big company, highly resourceful but painfully bureaucratic and too old fashioned
pros:
Chance to interact with a high number of subject matter experts in numerous fields
Diversity and global outreach 
Ability to work with multiple partners and customers; excellent opportunity to broaden your network 
Highly esteemed company in various industries 
Good place to learn & improve oneself 
Various role change opportunities within the company
Exposure to different projects
401k match 
Unlimited time-off
Travel opportunities
Job security
cons:
Too bureaucratic, approval processes are painfully long and tedious with too many cooks in the kitchen 

The company brands itself as a "tech" company but insists on old fashioned policies such as forcing employees to work from office and enforcing traditional dress code 

Lack of structure and organization especially in non-traditional business lines, constant chaos around quarter close

Upper management hasn't been truly supportive of emerging technologies until everyone else in the industry started to adopt them 

Work force is generally old, the company could do a better job in attracting younger talent and retaining existing talent 

It takes too long to get promoted unless you're in management 

Overwork culture is prevalent and can be widely accepted as the norm depending on your department 

Raises are too low

pros: Honeywell acquires companies with great products which are fun to sell. The people that work for the company are phenomenal. Honeywell is a corporate giant, so you get all of the perks of a company with deep pockets.
cons:
It's no secret that Honeywell's top priority is Wall Street - not their customers, employees, nor reputation in the field. 
It's a bureaucracy at it's finest. Red tape and hoops to jump through at every turn. Nothing is done quickly. It's not uncommon to require permission from people in different countries to complete trivial tasks.
Honestly Honeywell seems to be following the footsteps if General Electric...

pros: There is never a shortage of openings/opportunities because of all the people who burn out and quit.
cons:
Honeywell might be the most greedy company I've ever worked for. Yes, all companies need a certain amount of greed to be successful -- that's capitalism. But the hourly production workers -- the literal money makes -- are worked to the point that the old adage "blood from a turnip" comes to mind. The production workers are also not eligible for any bonuses, and the wages are barely competitive. The bonuses and pay are reserved for the "band 4" employees, which is basically mid level management and above. Every day we look at the "cost" of running our business, which is a balance that's tipped toward "how can we extract as much labor as humanly possible without incurring any additional cost?" For hourly production, it's mandatory 6-day work weeks for 3 years straight and for management it's failing to backfill when someone else leaves by dumping that workload onto someone else until they leave. 

But hey, unlimited PTO, amiright?

I also found out shortly after being hired that management often gets laid off for a few weeks at a time to cut the cost and pad the bottom line. We have deadlines on tasks that are to be completed each month, so when I asked my Sup if my workload for that time period would be reduced because, you know, I'm not being paid nor am I allowed to work, I was legitimately told "No." I clarified "So if I'm laid off for two weeks, I have to cram 4 weeks worth of work into a two-week period before I go?" Response: "Yes."

The epitome of profits over people. This company is to its employees what Wells Fargo was to its customers.

review_title: Upper management has no idea what's going on below them
job_title: Software Test Engineer in Houston, TX
pros:
You become upper management's favorite when your organization hits their profit margins.

Also IT is quick to get problems solved.
cons:
You become expendable when your organization doesn't make profit margins. 
Which seems obvious but it's also done without considering the context of the situation. When it's made to be that black or white, it takes the humanity out of management. 

The upper management corporate sludge is too thick to wade. I knew there was going to be some degree of that when my org got acquired, but I didn't know how deep it was. 6 layers of management stands between me and the CEO. It's just people managing people managing people. 

Also it's the workers at the bottom that shoulders the responsibility for the failures of upper management and gets no credit for their successes. 
Not to mention the duplicitous words of upper management. They kept saying how important we are to Honeywell and how the CEO's been personally asking about the status of our group, but then turn around and cut 70% of the team when our org didn't make any money due to their own poor management and decision making. I guess it was the technology that they acquired us for that is important, not the people that spend the last 4 years building it.

So my advice to the everyday employee: if you find your organization faltering in the profits, it might be time to find a new job before they make that decision for you.

job_title: Tool and Gage Inspector in Kansas City, MO
pros: Good pay, vacation time available after 3 months, can be relaxed work environment depending on department. This place is a classic example of a job where you can do the least amount possible for 30 years and retire.
cons: No other benefits to speak of. Very weak union, terrible health insurance, off shift differential pay is a joke, upper level management likes to micromanage, no retirement plan other than employee contributions to a 401k, yearly raises don't keep up with inflation. The company claims health and safety are a top priority but repeatedly show profits are most important. During inclement weather(a blizzard) when all other companies in the area are closed, roads are covered, and every news and law enforcement outlet recommend you stay off the roads, Honeywell still expects you to be at work but reminds you to drive carefully.

review_title: Amazing Opportunities, Work-Life Balance, and Atmosphere
job_title: Cyber Security Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Within the first day working at Honeywell it is already clear that work-life balance is important, managers are supportive, and everyone on the team is welcoming to new employees. The benefits are amazing compared to other businesses within the industry and professional development is major component of the culture.
cons: There have been no cons yet.

pros: Remuneration is above expectations. Work is generally challenging and offers steep learning curve in today’s tough business environment. Experience gained often prepares oneself for almost any challenges. There is great teamwork and drive for results. Culture is ok and policies are in place to ensure there is respect amongst employees.
cons: Career growth is stifling once a certain level is reached unless one is opened for a commercial role. The constant overpriming for results year on year regardless of business segment is mentally draining with endless hours of working. Not all fingers are of the same length. A lot of highly skilled talents have left or were let go and have been done a little too steep. Now struggling with resource constraint hence the endless work hours to maintain similar quality. job_title: Senior Program Manager (Digital Transformation & Enablement) in Charlotte, NC
pros: The first thing that stood out was Innovation & Technology. Working in the corporate headquarters they went all out in flexing their internal products, ingenuity, & advancements built into their facility. Lots of company perks like free snacks/food, free gym & parking access, partnership deals, product discounts, educational opportunities, & Hybrid Work schedule. From my experience the pay & benefits are above most competitors. Finally the internal education system they produced is thoroughly impressive which made ramping up quicker & more efficient.
cons:
Since pay & benefits are so competitive it's only natural performance expectations match. You immediately feel a need to outperform your standard which also means committing yourself past what you may have grown accustomed to. Say goodbye to the 40 hour work week, they usher in closer to 50. While I don't necessary think it's a Con they are very stringent about COVID restrictions & push vaccination requirements & mask utilization.

review_title: Employee salaries "if you want more money, work more overtime"
pros: At the end of the quarter, Honeywell usually supplies food for their employees as an incentive for them to work on weekends.
cons: My average yearly raise was less than 50 cents. Employees aren't awarded for their dedication. Every year, there is a "employee review" where your supervisor rates your work, productivity, and so forth. I was there for 4 years and each year I had a new supervisor. Many people didnt agree with their reviews and refused to sign them. These reviews determine your raise. The raises weren't enough to compensate for inflation. Honeywell has the mentality of "if you want more money, work more overtime" and that's not okay. If they gave proper raises, you wouldn't have to work those extra hours.

review_title: Great company to build a career
job_title: Sr Offering Management Specialist in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
I've been in Honeywell for almost 5 years now and in the time I've been here I've been given several opportunities to grow in my career. Support from the leadership teams I've been part of has been exceptional. Also, there's not only vertical movements within the org. but also lateral moves, making it really accessible to explore different areas of the business. 

Another thing I really like about Honeywell is the commitment to ethics and compliance as well as the entire structure they have to ensure this happens without having a single point reviewing that compliance is met. Instead there's a matrix of people and employees are empowered to be part of this matrix. Being a company with values really creates a very healthy work environment.
cons: Honeywell could provide some additional benefits and/or events for it's employees.

pros: Average benefits; every year the benefits are less and less and now they are really not comparable to peer companies. There is truly so much work to do that it is certainly possible to find something to your liking. Being such a big company, it is easier for some folks to pass through many years without really having to carry too much weight.
cons: Benefits are really lagging. Upper management is always super upbeat because things are so backwards that nobody can manage with transparency; it is a constant spin of reality vs what the company wants you to believe. There is so much work and not enough people to do it that they are constantly are looking for ways to shame you into putting "extra professional" time. And constantly coming up with made up terms to explain the total mismanagement at the technical level; latest one "under absorption" to let you know management overcommitted to too much work without enough workforce, so they expect everyone to work more hours to show higher "efficiency" but people can only keep up with 60+ hr weeks for so long, so people leave or stop working the "extra professional" time, the company will not hire more people, so the end result is that people are "under absorbed", or in other words not working enough to meet all the work that is out there. The work-life balance truly is atrocious in the last 5years or so (expectation is to be available 24/7).

review_title: Great opportunity for growth but lacking the tools needed for success
pros: Honeywell is a large company which allows nearly an infinite amount of lateral or progressive moves in position. The work environment is fast paced but challenges you on a daily basis.
cons: Due to recent supply chain issues and the simple fact that aerospace is a luxury industry when the economy suffers so does the company and the first thing that the company reaches for when the shareholders start loosing trust is to slash the workforce until cost of production is cheap and the quality even worse. The lack of training produced over the last few years has been a joke which is not the best to see when you are responsible for thousands of lives on the aircraft that your unit may be on.

pros:
- Lovely people mostly, the engineers can be a bit annoying tough.

cons:
- The job is very mundane and repetitive leaving your neck aching from looking through a microscope all day, not to forget the back pain from having your hands basically levitating all day. 
- If employed through an agency your very unlikely to get offered a full time permanent role which means no sick pay or holidays etc and lower wages.

pros: Cool products and some teams are very supportive of each other. The onsite teams look out for each other
cons:
Management and off site teams wait for you to do their work and then act like teachers or cops when you don't do exactly what they wanted. They take credit for all your work but never any of the blame. Quality is non-existent, they thing more process will make people work better but at the same time cut training staff in half.

They will take whatever time you give them so don't expect balanced work between departments.

The approval processes are crushing, you can't get any new equipment or equipment repaired without weeks of approvals. The only way to force movement is to tell the senior leaders that they are line down. Then everything moves fast.

I regularly ran into racist and sexist co-workers and heard these comments in the hall or during meetings.

review_title: Honeywell: we demand you relo and we will charge you back if you leave
pros: Free snacks, new campus in Charlotte, free parking, global projects
cons:
Do not relocate until you are 100% sure you're gonna a) like it and b) they're not planning to RIF your job 

While I learned a bunch, there was too many toxic leaders and I left after about a year and a half. The relo period bwas 2 years. Stupid me. 

I had positive reviews on my annual feedback session and even got my full bonus and a raise.

Guess what...they wanted full freight on my relo. 

Full. Freaking. Freight 

This amounted to almost $90,000. 

Yes you read that right.

Me: But I worked for a year and a half and did really well. Would you consider a making it 50%

HR: F U Pay me

Me: But this will cripple me. Other companies are a bit more lenient on their relo policies after time served.

HR: F U Pay me

Me: I can't do this without it impacting my livelihood and I may have to default on other financial obligations. Aren't you concerned about how this may affect your reputation?

HR: F U PAY ME..or we go to collections

It will absolutely happen to you. Buyer beware

review_title: Mixed Bag — Better than Most Big Companies
pros:
I’ve had a better support system than my previous jobs. My immediate team / function wasn’t the nicest, but made good connections across the country / world due to the regular work with international sites. It didn’t take long to start building a network, remotely and in person, that helped provide support, advice, and helped steer my career. I really love getting to work with and meet so many people from across the world, best experience I’ve had with international work at all. 

I’ve had some drama with coworkers and a mediocre manager, but less than I’m used too. There are a few cliques, but surprisingly few given the companies size. Allied Signal was not highly regarded, and those from Allied tend to be…gruff…at best. However, Garrett and the original Honeywell tend to brighten up the workplace.

If nothing else, Honeywell is huge, and offers a lot of possibilities and helps you along to them. Excited to move to a new role in a new function that’ll support teams worldwide, a dream come true.
cons:
Company wise, the work from home policy; it’s draconian at best. Many originally expected to be forced to go back full time in 2022, but enough employee surveys demanding WFH stay forced corporate to keep a flex schedule of three days in the office and two days at home. Nonetheless, it came, and still continues to come with a strong discouragement of work from home in general. I had to go back to work on a flex schedule on July 2021 while every other tech and aerospace company wasn’t even fathoming in office work. Fortunately, the flex schedule is here to stay, but the company’s resistance is a definite draw back. It’s primarily the CEO fighting it, seems he’s losing though, so the company is quietly starting to remove or silence opposition to WFH. 

Honeywell Aero is particularly disorganized to the point that it affects day to day work. The company historically has cut key functions that now underperform due to low staffing and other functions are expected to pick up the slack, just cause. Have to work with a number of people who lack the knowledge and understanding of our own internal systems and data while demanding an explanation for changes their function controls  — not realizing their function even does do the activity they’re questioning. 

The company is WAY too management heavy. I’m no stranger to elaborate corporate hierarchies, but Honeywell seemed to take overhead to the max. The company joke is that “at Honeywell, you’ll have two VPs, four directors, five managers,  and all their support staff on a status call given by one individual contributor who actually works a revenue generating product”. This company doesn’t seem to think that it’s questionable that 3 levels of a organization are on every call together — if the VP is in every call, why is there two directors and four managers on the same calls? You can see it costs the company a lot to have all this management by how quickly they remove perks like free coffee, the cafeteria, etc. to save a quick buck.

review_title: Honeywell could be a great place to work... but it just isn't.
pros: Financially Honeywell is a stable company that aims to take care of its shareholders. The people are great.
cons:
The company is in constant endless churn. I have had 3 different bosses in the last 2 years. Mid level management spends more time bringing new senior leadership teams up to speed than time spent focusing on customer needs. The inner workings of the company from its ERP systems to its Sourcing and HR policies are so complicated and riddled with red tape it is nearly impossible to carry out the company charter to impose any real, novel new ideas and solutions for its customers.
As a result, the company has a big employee retention problem. And its no wonder. In addition to points above, the company pays industry average salaries and wages. When being promoted, the worker will have to aggressively negotiate merit increases, otherwise HR will be happy to award you a pat on the back a consider you lucky with a 1-1.5%% increase in salary to award you for taking on more responsibilities. Which in many cases dis enchants employees and causes the employee to take a new job elsewhere. There are 0 thing this company does to retain talent. No retention bonuses, vesting stock or stock options, or pensions. Honeywell has an industry average contribution to your 401K. There is a no vacation policy. This is sold to the employee as "you can take as much time off as you want- as long as your boss approves it". This leaves senior long term employees who've spent a career earning more vacation time every year with basically the same amount of vacation time as the new hire right out of college. And don't expect HR to be on your side. Your HR rep has no power to advocate on your behalf when it comes to title, merit increases, bonuses or benefits.

review_title: Typical big company, highly resourceful but painfully bureaucratic and too old fashioned
pros:
Chance to interact with a high number of subject matter experts in numerous fields
Diversity and global outreach 
Ability to work with multiple partners and customers; excellent opportunity to broaden your network 
Highly esteemed company in various industries 
Good place to learn & improve oneself

Exposure to different projects
401k match 
Unlimited time-off
Travel opportunities
Job security
cons:
Too bureaucratic, approval processes are painfully long and tedious with too many cooks in the kitchen 

The company brands itself as a "tech" company but insists on old fashioned policies such as forcing employees to work from office and enforcing traditional dress code 

Lack of structure and organization especially in non-traditional business lines, constant chaos around quarter close

Upper management hasn't been truly supportive of emerging technologies until everyone else in the industry started to adopt them 

Work force is generally old, the company could do a better job in attracting younger talent and retaining existing talent 

It takes too long to get promoted unless you're in management 

Overwork culture is prevalent and can be widely accepted as the norm depending on your department 

Raises are too low

review_title: A Mix of Good and Bad
job_title: Lead Project Engineer in Charlotte, NC
pros:
Some of the positives:
- Honeywell is working on some amazing things and it is nice to be part of that.
- The new headquarters in uptown Charlotte is a great showcase of their technology. 
- Honeywell places a strong emphasis on employee development and some of their recent efforts are admirable (e.g., no meeting day to focus on employee development).
cons:
Your experience here will differ by function, but here are some things to consider:
- Honeywell is extremely process-driven. Process is important but too much process is stifling. 
- Complex systems with no workarounds take a heavy administrative burden... as a project manager, it feels less like managing a project and more like managing a tool. 
- Honeywell wants employees in the office 3 days a week and managers will be notified if their team is not compliant. Does not matter if you have no coworkers in the office and your teams are dispersed globally.
- The organization structure is very complex. It is often very difficult to understand who does what. Tasks that should take a day can take weeks because of various approvals required and trying to find the actual right person who owns the next action.
- Meeting paralysis... so many meetings. Some necessary, some not. 
- Metrics overload... lot of time spent managing to metrics. Some of this is important but Honeywell takes it too far to the point it drives non-value added behaviors. 
- Benefits cost - highest cost of healthcare benefits I have seen.

pros: Very thorough interview process that obviously ensures that only the right candidate gets hired.

pros: Nice to Work in the IT
cons: More process Oriented on IT SOlution

pros: There is never a shortage of openings/opportunities because of all the people who burn out and quit.
cons:
Honeywell might be the most greedy company I've ever worked for. Yes, all companies need a certain amount of greed to be successful -- that's capitalism. But the hourly production workers -- the literal money makes -- are worked to the point that the old adage "blood from a turnip" comes to mind. The production workers are also not eligible for any bonuses, and the wages are barely competitive. The bonuses and pay are reserved for the "band 4" employees, which is basically mid level management and above. Every day we look at the "cost" of running our business, which is a balance that's tipped toward "how can we extract as much labor as humanly possible without incurring any additional cost?" For hourly production, it's mandatory 6-day work weeks for 3 years straight and for management it's failing to backfill when someone else leaves by dumping that workload onto someone else until they leave. 

But hey, unlimited PTO, amiright?

I also found out shortly after being hired that management often gets laid off for a few weeks at a time to cut the cost and pad the bottom line. We have deadlines on tasks that are to be completed each month, so when I asked my Sup if my workload for that time period would be reduced because, you know, I'm not being paid nor am I allowed to work, I was legitimately told "No." I clarified "So if I'm laid off for two weeks, I have to cram 4 weeks worth of work into a two-week period before I go?" Response: "Yes."

The epitome of profits over people. This company is to its employees what Wells Fargo was to its customers.

review_title: Upper management has no idea what's going on below them
job_title: Software Test Engineer in Houston, TX
pros:
You become upper management's favorite when your organization hits their profit margins.

Also IT is quick to get problems solved.
cons:
You become expendable when your organization doesn't make profit margins. 
Which seems obvious but it's also done without considering the context of the situation. When it's made to be that black or white, it takes the humanity out of management. 

The upper management corporate sludge is too thick to wade. I knew there was going to be some degree of that when my org got acquired, but I didn't know how deep it was. 6 layers of management stands between me and the CEO. It's just people managing people managing people. 

Also it's the workers at the bottom that shoulders the responsibility for the failures of upper management and gets no credit for their successes. 
Not to mention the duplicitous words of upper management. They kept saying how important we are to Honeywell and how the CEO's been personally asking about the status of our group, but then turn around and cut 70% of the team when our org didn't make any money due to their own poor management and decision making. I guess it was the technology that they acquired us for that is important, not the people that spend the last 4 years building it.

So my advice to the everyday employee: if you find your organization faltering in the profits, it might be time to find a new job before they make that decision for you.

cons: Career growth is stifling once a certain level is reached unless one is opened for a commercial role. The constant overpriming for results year on year regardless of business segment is mentally draining with endless hours of working. Not all fingers are of the same length. A lot of highly skilled talents have left or were let go and have been done a little too steep. Now struggling with resource constraint hence the endless work hours to maintain similar quality. Hiring have restarted but not addressing an experience gap. It will be a while to close the experience gap.

job_title: Senior Program Manager (Digital Transformation & Enablement) in Charlotte, NC
pros: The first thing that stood out was Innovation & Technology. Working in the corporate headquarters they went all out in flexing their internal products, ingenuity, & advancements built into their facility. Lots of company perks like free snacks/food, free gym & parking access, partnership deals, product discounts, educational opportunities, & Hybrid Work schedule. From my experience the pay & benefits are above most competitors. Finally the internal education system they produced is thoroughly impressive which made ramping up quicker & more efficient.
cons:
Since pay & benefits are so competitive it's only natural performance expectations match. You immediately feel a need to outperform your standard which also means committing yourself past what you may have grown accustomed to. Say goodbye to the 40 hour work week, they usher in closer to 50. While I don't necessary think it's a Con they are very stringent about COVID restrictions & push vaccination requirements & mask utilization.
